newsitem.title: GERMANY: Reuters German Advertising & Media Digest -June 20.
newsitem.headline: Reuters German Advertising & Media Digest -June 20.

text.p: REUTERS GERMAN ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST
News from Reuters and the German press on Advertising, Marketing, Media, the Internet, Brand-name Products and Consumer Trends
ADVERTISING & MARKETING:

DUESSELDORF - Germany's largest brewing and drinks concern, Brau und Brunnen, says it's cutting its advertising and marketing budget from 80 million marks to 60 million marks (from $46 million to $35 million) and consolidating its brands, including Jever, Brinkhoff's, Schultheiss and Schloesser Alt. The consolidation comes as the group says it will remain in losses in the current year.
(Reuter)

FRANKFURT - Saatchi & Saatchi's Frankfurt office has won the pitch for beer-brand Beck's 30-million-mark ad budget, previously held by DDB. Saatchi's task is to give Beck's current "Sail away" image a deeper emotional tone. (Horizont)

HAMBURG - Wunderman Cato Johnson in Germany emerges as the most successful German agency at the New York Festival, snapping up gold and silver medals in the print and radio advertising sections. Second-best German entrant was Springer & Jacoby, which picked up gold and bronze, while Scholz & Friends came away with one gold. German firms owon 12 medals. Wunderman Cato Johnson, which is owned by Young & Rubicam Inc, has its European headquarters in Eschborn, Germany.(Reuter)
MEDIA & THE INTERNET:

Bonn - Pay-TV group Premiere has signed a long-term film rights deal with Fox and Dreamworks, a Hollywood studio, under which it receives subscription and pay-per-view rights for all feature films they produce. (Reuter)

NUREMBERG - The consortium looking to acquire a majority in printing and publishing group Sebaldus wants a stake of at least 85 percent and if possible to go for a full acquisition. The group, led by German holding group DBAG, France's Alpha and another investor, says it has made an offer accordingly.(Reuter)

BERLIN - Private TV broadcaster Sat.1 is putting up six million marks for the Berlin-Brandenburg film promotion initiative and will be seeking a place on its film board in 1999. Sat.1 is planning three co-productions in Berlin during this year and 1998. (Reuter)

MUNICH - Rights management company GEMA says it paid out more money to artists on its books in 1996 than in the year before, with total royalty and other payments hitting 1.37 billion marks. The main recipients were composers, text authors and music publishers. (Reuter)

KASSEL - This century's last five-yearly staging of "documenta X", Germany's leading international art exhibition, opens on Saturday with its main theme based on a past-future contrast. documenta, which calls itself the "world's most important exhibition of contemporary art", will this year use media including Internet, film, theatre and travel diaries as well as more traditional visual arts. (Reuter)
BRAND-NAME PRODUCTS & MARKETS:

MUNICH - Germany's economy is picking up, albeit rather slowly, Ifo economic research institute says. Economic growth is forecast at between 2.0 and 2.5 percent this year, rising to 2.75 percent in 1998, increased growth that will nonetheless do little for Germany's record jobless levels, Ifo forecasts. (Reuter).

ESSEN - Karstadt, Germany's largest department store group, announces slowdown in business during the first three months of 1997, but says it is still on target to improve earnings this year. Karstadt group sales fell 2.3 percent in the first quarter to 5.979 billion marks and in the first five months both its Karstadt and Hertie chains lost trade on a same-store basis. Karstadt also unveils a new way of presenting its products, using product categories such as multimedia, sport and leisure. (Reuter)

HAMBURG - Despite recent strong profit gains, Volkswagen tells shareholders it plans to cut costs further, with production, distribution and administration all targeted for savings. VW last year more than doubled profit to 678 million marks and has forecast further growth in 1997.
(Reuter)

HAMBURG - Eduscho, a Bremen-based coffee-roaster, announces another price increase, saying that from June 30 it will be adding 50 pfennigs a half-kilo to most of its coffee types. The increase, which Eduscho attributes to higher raw material costs and a stronger dollar, means 500 grammes of its coffee will cost between 8.99 and und 10.49 marks. (Reuter)

DARMSTADT - German drugs group Merck says its Toronto-based unit Genpharm on June 17 received a temporary registration from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to market a generic version of the active agent Ranitidin used in the stomach ulcer drug Zantac. (Reuter)
